title: Quiz 1: Fundamentals of Community Diagnosis
description: Assess your understanding of the core concepts, the 4As of PHC, and essential health indicators.

questions.question: What is the core definition of Community Diagnosis?

options.text: A process where health workers and community members identify priority problems and plan actions together.
The clinical treatment of individual patients within a specific village setting.
A government census to determine the total population of a district.
The distribution of medicines to households based on income levels.

questions.explanation: Community diagnosis is defined as a process through which health workers together with members of the community identify the community's priority health problems, and together make plans of action and implement them.
questions.hint: It involves collaboration between health workers and the community.

questions.question: Match the tool or action to the correct type of diagnosis:
questions.explanation: Patient diagnosis uses clinical tools like BP machines (sphygmomanometer), while community diagnosis uses survey tools like maps and questionnaires.
questions.hint: Think about whether the tool assesses one person or a whole area.

questions.question: Which of the following are the '4 As' of Primary Health Care mentioned in the context of community participation?

options.text: Acceptability
Accessibility
Affordability
Availability
Accountability

questions.explanation: The four As essential for community participation are Acceptability, Accessibility, Affordability, and Availability.
questions.hint: Accountability is important but not one of the specific '4 As' listed.

questions.question: Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is the probability of dying between birth and exactly ___BLANK___ year of age expressed per 1,000 live births.
questions.explanation: IMR specifically measures the death rate of infants under the age of one year.
questions.hint: It marks the end of infancy.

questions.question: A negative Rate of Natural Increase (RNI) indicates that the population is growing rapidly.
questions.explanation: A negative RNI means the death rate is greater than the birth rate, so the population is decreasing.
questions.hint: Think about what happens if deaths exceed births.

questions.question: What term describes a characteristic within a study sample (like weight or age) whose value changes among the study subjects?
questions.explanation: A variable is a characteristic whose value changes (varies) among the study subjects.
questions.hint: It is the opposite of a constant.

questions.question: Arrange the basic steps of a Patient Diagnosis in the correct order:
questions.explanation: The logical flow is gathering info (history), examining, deciding the problem (diagnosis), treating it, and checking if it worked (evaluation).
questions.hint: You must listen to the patient before you can treat them.

questions.question: Analyze the table below regarding vital statistics. Which formula correctly represents the Crude Birth Rate (CBR)?

richContent.content:
IndicatorDefinition
IMRInfant deaths / Live births x 1000
CDRTotal deaths / Mid-year population x 1000

options.text: Total Births / Mid-year Population × 1,000
Total Births / Total Deaths × 100
Live Births / Infant Deaths × 1,000
Mid-year Population / Total Births × 100

questions.explanation: Crude Birth Rate is calculated by dividing the total number of births in a year by the mid-year population and expressing it per 1,000.
questions.hint: It is similar to the CDR formula shown in the table but for births.

questions.question: What is the key difference between Incidence and Prevalence?

options.text: Incidence counts NEW cases; Prevalence counts TOTAL (new + old) cases.
Incidence counts OLD cases; Prevalence counts NEW cases.
Incidence is for chronic diseases; Prevalence is for acute diseases.
Incidence is a percentage; Prevalence is a ratio.

questions.explanation: Incidence gives information on the number of NEW cases occurring over a specific time, while Prevalence gives the TOTAL number of cases at a particular time.

questions.question: Why is it important to select ONLY priority health problems during a community diagnosis?

options.text: Resources are limited and not all problems can be solved at once.
The community does not care about minor problems.
Health workers are only trained to handle major diseases.
Government policy forbids treating more than 3 problems.

questions.explanation: There are not enough resources to solve all health problems, so priorities must be selected that the community can practically address.
questions.hint: Think about budget and manpower constraints.
